text:
In this video, you’ll see how to grant
 Amazon CodeWhisperer access
using Active Directory credentials.

With this capability, you can map users 
and groups from Active Directory into

IAM Identity Center, and then assign 
CodeWhisperer access to specific users

or groups so they can access CodeWhisperer 
from an IDE using their Active Directory credentials.

To get started, let’s navigate to IAM 
Identity Center and create a connection

between our AWS account and 
our Active Directory environment.

Since this is our first time visiting IAM Identity 
Center, we’ll enable it for our AWS organization.
Next, we’ll choose our identity source.

The identity source is where you 
administer users and groups,

and is the service that 
authenticates your users.

By default, IAM Identity Center 
uses an internal directory of users,

so we’ll change this to an 
Active Directory environment.
Next, we’ll choose our Active Directory.

Finally, we’ll confirm that we want to change 
the identity source and then make the change.

Now, let’s start the guided setup 
to configure our sync scope.

First, we have the option to map Identity Center 
attributes to our Active Directory attributes.
In this example, we’ll continue with the defaults.
Next, we have the option to sync specific

users or groups from our Active 
Directory into IAM Identity Center.

Let’s add our developers group so we 
can assign it CodeWhisperer permissions.
We’ll review and save the configuration.

Now, let’s resume the sync to connect our 
Active Directory group with IAM Identity Center.

We’ll navigate to the Users tab and refresh 
the page to see the status of the sync.
Here is the one user in our developers group.

Next, we’ll navigate to CodeWhisperer 
to configure access for this group.

We’ll assign CodeWhisperer to 
all users in the developer group.

CodeWhisperer access is now 
set up for our developer group.

Let’s locate the Start URL so we 
can distribute it to the group’s users.

This URL is required for users to 
access CodeWhisperer in their IDEs.
Let’s copy it.

Additionally, we’ll note 
the AWS Region we’re in.

Let’s switch to the perspective of the user 
in the developer group and open our IDE.
For this example, our IDE is Visual Studio Code.

First, we’ll install the AWS Toolkit 
extension, which includes CodeWhisperer.

Next, we’ll configure the 
CodeWhisperer extension.

We need to create a connection from 
VS Code to our AWS environment.

To do this, we’ll sign in to our developer 
account with IAM Identity Center.

We’ll provide the Start URL we 
copied earlier and our AWS Region.

We’ll copy the access code and proceed 
to the IAM Identity Center login page.

We'll sign in using our 
Active Directory credentials.

We’ll allow AWS Toolkit for 
VS Code to access our data.
Now let’s return to the VS Code window.

Our IDE is now connected to 
CodeWhisperer with IAM Identity Center.

Let’s open a new text file and test whether 
CodeWhisperer will start making code suggestions.
We’ll work in Python.

As expected, when we begin to type, CodeWhisperer 
is generating suggestions to complete the line.

You’ve just seen how to grant Amazon CodeWhisperer 
access using Active Directory credentials.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
